title: Ken Morrison dies aged 85 after a short illness
text: Share The company opened its first supermarket, 'Victoria', in the Girlington district of Bradford in 1961. In 1967 he led the company on to the stock market in London in a share offer which was 174 times oversubscribed as more than 80,000 investors tried to buy a stake. Ken Morrison outside the then new Morrison's supermarket store in Erith, Kent Expansion across the North of England continued and in 1998 Morrisons opened its first store in the South - in Erith, Kent - before opening its 100th store in its centenary year in 1999. Infamously, he described former Morrisons boss Dalton Philips's strategy as 'b ' in 2014, as the then-chief executive faced intense pressure amid sliding sales and a fierce supermarket price war. Sir Ken, who was one of Yorkshire's richest men, stood down as chairman and chief executive of Morrisons in 2008. Sir Ken received his CBE in 1990 and was knighted in the 2000 new year's honours list for services to the food retailing industry. He lived on the outskirts of York, in Myton Hall, North Yorkshire, with his wife Lynne, and his two youngest children. A statement from Sir Ken's family said he died peacefully at home in North Yorkshire. It read: 'We are very sad to share the news that Sir Ken died today aged 85 following a short illness. He died peacefully at home in North Yorkshire with his family. 'Sir Ken was, of course, a unique figure in the history of grocery retailing in the UK, for more than half a century being the driving force at the heart of Morrisons as it grew from two market stalls to become one of the UK's largest retailers.
